elements.content: Searching for new host materials tailored for the high proton conductivity is highly desirable for the new generation of fuel cell system. We report here an anion-exchangeable cationic metal organic framework with the formula of [Ce­(Ccbp)2]­Br0.25Cl0.75·​6H2O·​2DMF (compound 1), which is constructed through the self-assembly of zwitterionic-based ligands H2Ccbp­Br (H2Ccbp­Br = 4-carboxy-1-(4-carboxy­benzyl)­pyridinium bromide) and (NH4)2­Ce­(NO3)6. During the investigation of humidity-dependent proton conduction behavior, we observed a rare case of rapid water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transformation from compound 1 to a neutral chain [Ce­(Ccbp)3­(H2O)3]·​8H2O (compound 2). This structural transformation originates from the coordination of water to Ce­(III) metal centers, distortion of ligands, and the soft nature of the cationic framework 1, as probed and confirmed by a variety of investigations including color change, water vapor adsorption measurement, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements, IR and UV–vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis. As a consequence, this process introduces significant amounts of both coordinated and lattice water molecules into the structure, further giving rise to a decent water-assisted proton conductivity of 1.104 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 368 K and 95% relative humidity.
elements.clean_text: Searching for new host materials tailored for the high proton conductivity is highly desirable for the new generation of fuel cell system. We report here an anion-exchangeable cationic metal organic framework with the formula of [Ce(Ccbp)2]Br0.25Cl0.75⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (compound 1), which is constructed through the self-assembly of zwitterionic-based ligands H2CcbpBr (H2CcbpBr = 4-carboxy-1-(4-carboxybenzyl)pyridinium bromide) and (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6. During the investigation of humidity-dependent proton conduction behavior, we observed a rare case of rapid water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transformation from compound 1 to a neutral chain [Ce(Ccbp)3(H2O)3]⋅8H2O (compound 2). This structural transformation originates from the coordination of water to Ce(III) metal centers, distortion of ligands, and the soft nature of the cationic framework 1, as probed and confirmed by a variety of investigations including color change, water vapor adsorption measurement, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements, IR and UV-vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis. As a consequence, this process introduces significant amounts of both coordinated and lattice water molecules into the structure, further giving rise to a decent water-assisted proton conductivity of 1.104 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 368 K and 95% relative humidity.

elements.content: A rare example of water-induced structural transformation from a cationic framework to a water-rich neutral chain is observed, as probed and confirmed by a variety of investigations including color change, water vapor adsorption measurement, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements, IR and UV−vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis.
elements.clean_text: A rare example of water-induced structural transformation from a cationic framework to a water-rich neutral chain is observed, as probed and confirmed by a variety of investigations including color change, water vapor adsorption measurement, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements, IR and UV-vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have extensively been explored during the last two decades owing to not only their advantageous features in terms of high surface area, intriguing and uniform architecture but also their tunable and flexible pore size and corresponding diversity as a result of versatile coordination mode of metal centers and abundant selections of bridging ligands. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase (SC-SC) transformations have been reported for many flexible MOFs, which allows for direct visualization of the structural transition and, therefore, the underlying transformation mechanism through single-crystal X-ray diffraction, leading to change and tuning of physical and chemical properties including color, stability, luminescence, magnetism, gas adsorption, ion-exchange capability, catalytic activity, ionic conductivity, etc. In general, phase transformation of MOFs includes changes in geometry and coordination number, interpenetration, framework distortion, and structural dimensionality, whereas combined changes in the packing arrays and overall net charge of the framework are relatively scarce.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have extensively been explored during the last two decades owing to not only their advantageous features in terms of high surface area, intriguing and uniform architecture but also their tunable and flexible pore size and corresponding diversity as a result of versatile coordination mode of metal centers and abundant selections of bridging ligands. Single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase (SC-SC) transformations have been reported for many flexible MOFs, which allows for direct visualization of the structural transition and, therefore, the underlying transformation mechanism through single-crystal X-ray diffraction, leading to change and tuning of physical and chemical properties including color, stability, luminescence, magnetism, gas adsorption, ion-exchange capability, catalytic activity, ionic conductivity, etc. In general, phase transformation of MOFs includes changes in geometry and coordination number, interpenetration, framework distortion, and structural dimensionality, whereas combined changes in the packing arrays and overall net charge of the framework are relatively scarce.

elements.content: On the other hand, MOFs have been explored as new platforms for proton conduction due to their defined frameworks with chemically adjustable porosities/channels. Although their practical applications are still limited currently, the emergence of proton-conducting MOFs shed light on a better understanding of the proton transportation pathways and mechanisms at the molecular level based on their comprehensive structural information. Proton-conducting MOFs can generally be divided into two categories. The majority consists of water-assisted proton-conducting MOFs that can only be operated in a water-mediated environment below 373 K. In this case, water molecules play a key role in the process of proton conduction for water-mediated proton-conducting MOFs by contributing to the hydrogen-bonding network and acting as direct proton carriers. The other category contains only a handful of cases, which can be operated under anhydrous conditions in the intermediate temperature range of 373–573 K. This class of materials often involves dehydration or phase transition processes at relatively high temperatures, where protons are partially activated. A recent example shows that a crystalline coordination polymer containing an extremely dense and thermally stable hydrogen bond network exhibits combined ultrahigh water-assisted proton conductivities in the low temperature region and sustainable anhydrous proton conductivity at temperatures higher than 453 K. Nevertheless, introducing abundant proton-rich molecules such as water into the crystal structure is a feasible strategy to enhance the proton conductivity of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, MOFs have been explored as new platforms for proton conduction due to their defined frameworks with chemically adjustable porosities/channels. Although their practical applications are still limited currently, the emergence of proton-conducting MOFs shed light on a better understanding of the proton transportation pathways and mechanisms at the molecular level based on their comprehensive structural information. Proton-conducting MOFs can generally be divided into two categories. The majority consists of water-assisted proton-conducting MOFs that can only be operated in a water-mediated environment below 373 K. In this case, water molecules play a key role in the process of proton conduction for water-mediated proton-conducting MOFs by contributing to the hydrogen-bonding network and acting as direct proton carriers. The other category contains only a handful of cases, which can be operated under anhydrous conditions in the intermediate temperature range of 373-573 K. This class of materials often involves dehydration or phase transition processes at relatively high temperatures, where protons are partially activated. A recent example shows that a crystalline coordination polymer containing an extremely dense and thermally stable hydrogen bond network exhibits combined ultrahigh water-assisted proton conductivities in the low temperature region and sustainable anhydrous proton conductivity at temperatures higher than 453 K. Nevertheless, introducing abundant proton-rich molecules such as water into the crystal structure is a feasible strategy to enhance the proton conductivity of MOFs.

elements.content: There are several ways to introduce additional water into the structure. The most facile one is the intercalation of water into the void space of MOFs to possibly form lattice water molecules; despite that their thermal stability is limited. One other way is utilizing the coordinating capability of water and forming an M–H2O bond with the presence of coordinated water molecules. This strategy is particularly applicable for the flexible MOFs with a high-valent metal center containing coordinating-available open metal sites. In some cases, water substitution on coordination sites may also lead to structural transformations. f-blocks including lanthanides and uranium based MOFs fall into this category owing to their high charge densities and, therefore, the hydrophilic nature. However, these metal cations also tightly bind to carboxylate ligands, giving rise to the fact that the majority of f-block based MOFs are hydrolytically stable. Only a handful of lanthanide MOFs are reported to undergo water-induced structural transformation.
elements.clean_text: There are several ways to introduce additional water into the structure. The most facile one is the intercalation of water into the void space of MOFs to possibly form lattice water molecules; despite that their thermal stability is limited. One other way is utilizing the coordinating capability of water and forming an M-H2O bond with the presence of coordinated water molecules. This strategy is particularly applicable for the flexible MOFs with a high-valent metal center containing coordinating-available open metal sites. In some cases, water substitution on coordination sites may also lead to structural transformations. f-blocks including lanthanides and uranium based MOFs fall into this category owing to their high charge densities and, therefore, the hydrophilic nature. However, these metal cations also tightly bind to carboxylate ligands, giving rise to the fact that the majority of f-block based MOFs are hydrolytically stable. Only a handful of lanthanide MOFs are reported to undergo water-induced structural transformation.

elements.content: Herein, we report a very unusual case of water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transitions with water molecules included in the framework from a 3D lanthanide porous cationic MOF [Ce­(Ccbp)2]­Br0.25Cl0.75·​6H2O·​2DMF (denoted as compound 1, H2Ccbp­Br = 4-carboxy-1-(4-carboxy­benzyl)­pyridinium bromide) to a water-rich 1D neutral chain structure [Ce­(Ccbp)3­(H2O)3]·​8H2O (denoted as compound 2). This process was originally probed by the sharp humidity-dependent feature of the proton-conducting behavior and followed by comprehensive characterizations including structural, spectroscopic, and thermal property measurements. As a consequence of introducing large amounts of lattice and coordinated water molecules into the structure of compound 2, its proton conductivity reaches 1.104 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 368 K and 95% relative humidity.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a very unusual case of water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transitions with water molecules included in the framework from a 3D lanthanide porous cationic MOF [Ce(Ccbp)2]Br0.25Cl0.75⋅6H2O⋅2DMF (denoted as compound 1, H2CcbpBr = 4-carboxy-1-(4-carboxybenzyl)pyridinium bromide) to a water-rich 1D neutral chain structure [Ce(Ccbp)3(H2O)3]⋅8H2O (denoted as compound 2). This process was originally probed by the sharp humidity-dependent feature of the proton-conducting behavior and followed by comprehensive characterizations including structural, spectroscopic, and thermal property measurements. As a consequence of introducing large amounts of lattice and coordinated water molecules into the structure of compound 2, its proton conductivity reaches 1.104 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 368 K and 95% relative humidity.

elements.content:
All reagents were commercially available and were used without further purification. The H2Ccbp­Br ligand was synthesized according to the literature method.

Characterizations

The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with a Vario EL CHNOS elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected from 5° to 50° with a step of 0.02°, and the time for data collection was 0.2 s on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) and a Lynxeye one-dimensional detector. Scanning electron microscopy/​energy-dispersive spectroscopy (SEM/EDS) images and data were collected using an FEI Quanta 200FEG. The energy of the electron beam was 30 kV, and the spectrum acquisition time was 100 s. The FTIR spectra were collected on a Thermo Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with KBr pellets. Luminescence spectra were collected on a Horiba FL-3 spectrofluorometer. The UV–vis spectroscopy was collected by using a Thermo Scientific GENESYS 10S UV–vis Spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All reagents were commercially available and were used without further purification. The H2CcbpBr ligand was synthesized according to the literature method. 

Characterizations

The elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out with a Vario EL CHNOS elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected from 5° to 50° with a step of 0.02°, and the time for data collection was 0.2 s on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) and a Lynxeye one-dimensional detector. Scanning electron microscopy/energy-dispersive spectroscopy (SEM/EDS) images and data were collected using an FEI Quanta 200FEG. The energy of the electron beam was 30 kV, and the spectrum acquisition time was 100 s. The FTIR spectra were collected on a Thermo Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with KBr pellets. Luminescence spectra were collected on a Horiba FL-3 spectrofluorometer. The UV-vis spectroscopy was collected by using a Thermo Scientific GENESYS 10S UV-vis Spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of 4-(bromo­methyl)­benzoic acid (3.5 g, 15 mmol) and ethyl isonicotinate (2.3 g, 15 mmol) in 50 mL of CH3CN was refluxed for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled down to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried at 50 °C to give the ester of H2Ccbp­Br. The resultant was dissolved in 15% HCl (w/w; 60 mL) and was subsequently refluxed for 6 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white power, which was recrystallized in H2O to afford colorless crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligand H2CcbpBr

A mixture of 4-(bromomethyl)benzoic acid (3.5 g, 15 mmol) and ethyl isonicotinate (2.3 g, 15 mmol) in 50 mL of CH3CN was refluxed for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled down to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried at 50 °C to give the ester of H2CcbpBr. The resultant was dissolved in 15% HCl (w/w; 60 mL) and was subsequently refluxed for 6 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white power, which was recrystallized in H2O to afford colorless crystals.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction. A reactant mixture of H2Ccbp­Br (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), Ce­(NH4)2­(NO3)6 (54.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (1 mL) was loaded into a 20 mL glass vial and heated at 100 °C for 5 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The product was obtained as dark yellow block-shaped crystals (yield: 67% based on cerium), recovered by filtration, and subsequently washed with DMF and ethanol. Yield: ca. 55.3% (based on Ce­(NH4)2­(NO3)6). Anal. Calcd for C34H56­O16N4­Cl0.75Br0.25­Ce: C, 45.02%; H, 4.634%; N, 6.17%; Found: C, 44.15%; H, 4.208%; N, 5.947%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was conducted to verify the purity of compound 1 (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Compound 1 

Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction. A reactant mixture of H2CcbpBr (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6 (54.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (1 mL) was loaded into a 20 mL glass vial and heated at 100 °C for 5 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The product was obtained as dark yellow block-shaped crystals (yield: 67% based on cerium), recovered by filtration, and subsequently washed with DMF and ethanol. Yield: ca. 55.3% (based on Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6). Anal. Calcd for C34H56O16N4Cl0.75Br0.25Ce: C, 45.02%; H, 4.634%; N, 6.17%; Found: C, 44.15%; H, 4.208%; N, 5.947%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was conducted to verify the purity of compound 1 (Figure S1).

elements.content: Measurements were carried out using a Quantachrome Autosorb Gas Sorption analyzer IQ2. The samples of compound 1 were soaked into a methanol solution of LiCl, and the solutions were refreshed every 6 h for 3 days. Similarly, the samples were further treated with methanol to remove the excess LiCl in the solvent (soaked in methanol for 3 d and fresh methanol was added every 8 h). After decanting the methanol extract, the samples were dried under a dynamic vacuum (<10–3 Torr) at room temperature overnight. Before adsorption measurements, the samples were activated using the “outgas” function of the surface area analyzer for 8 h at 80 °C. N2 adsorption measurement for compound 1 was carried at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath. Water vapor sorption was performed at 293 K in a deionized water solution. The detecting pressures range from 0 to 760 Torr.
elements.clean_text:
N2 and Water Vapor Adsorption Measurements

Measurements were carried out using a Quantachrome Autosorb Gas Sorption analyzer IQ2. The samples of compound 1 were soaked into a methanol solution of LiCl, and the solutions were refreshed every 6 h for 3 days. Similarly, the samples were further treated with methanol to remove the excess LiCl in the solvent (soaked in methanol for 3 d and fresh methanol was added every 8 h). After decanting the methanol extract, the samples were dried under a dynamic vacuum (<10-3 Torr) at room temperature overnight. Before adsorption measurements, the samples were activated using the "outgas" function of the surface area analyzer for 8 h at 80 °C. N2 adsorption measurement for compound 1 was carried at 77 K in a liquid nitrogen bath. Water vapor sorption was performed at 293 K in a deionized water solution. The detecting pressures range from 0 to 760 Torr.

elements.content: A 50 mg portion of crystals of compound 1 was added to 10 mL of water. After the change of the color from dark yellow to light yellow occurring almost instantly, the crystals were filtrated and identified by PXRD analysis, verifying the purity of compound 2 (Figure S1), which is a solid proof of the complete phase transformation from compound 1 to compound 2.
elements.clean_text:
Water-Induced Structural Transformation

A 50 mg portion of crystals of compound 1 was added to 10 mL of water. After the change of the color from dark yellow to light yellow occurring almost instantly, the crystals were filtrated and identified by PXRD analysis, verifying the purity of compound 2 (Figure S1), which is a solid proof of the complete phase transformation from compound 1 to compound 2.

elements.content: As-synthesized compound 1 (200 mg) was added into 200 mL of 0.001 mmol/L CrO4 2– (typically in the oxo anionic form of CrO4 2– depending on the pH and concentration) DMF solution. The resulting mixture was mildly stirred for 100 h at room temperature, allowing for complete anion exchange. During the process, the concentration of CrO4 2– in a supernatant was determined at different intervals of time by UV–vis spectroscopy. After 100 h, the solid in the solution was filtered, rinsed with deionized water, dried in the air, and used for PXRD measurement.
elements.clean_text:
CrO4 2- Exchange Experiments

As-synthesized compound 1 (200 mg) was added into 200 mL of 0.001 mmol/L CrO4 2- (typically in the oxo anionic form of CrO4 2- depending on the pH and concentration) DMF solution. The resulting mixture was mildly stirred for 100 h at room temperature, allowing for complete anion exchange. During the process, the concentration of CrO4 2- in a supernatant was determined at different intervals of time by UV-vis spectroscopy. After 100 h, the solid in the solution was filtered, rinsed with deionized water, dried in the air, and used for PXRD measurement.

elements.content: The powders were prepared by grinding the samples of compound 1 and compound 2 into a homogeneous powder with a mortar and pestle. The powders were then added to a standard die, sandwiched between two stainless steel electrodes, and pressed at 10 MPa for 5 min. The impedances were measured with a frequency response analyzer/​potentiostat (PARSTAT 4000, Ametek, USA) over a frequency range from 0.1 Hz to 10 MHz, with a quasi-four probe electrochemical cell and an applied ac voltage of 500 mV. Measurements were taken in the temperature range of 30–90% RH with 90 °C and 30–90 °C with 90% RH (controlled by using an HDHWHS-50 incubator). Zview software was used to extrapolate impedance data results by means of an equivalent circuit simulation to complete the Nyquist plots and obtain the resistance values. Conductivity was calculated using the following equation: σ = L/(RS), where σ is the conductivity (S cm−1), L is the measured sample thickness (cm), S is the electrode area (cm2), and R is the impedance (Ω).
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductivity Measurement

The powders were prepared by grinding the samples of compound 1 and compound 2 into a homogeneous powder with a mortar and pestle. The powders were then added to a standard die, sandwiched between two stainless steel electrodes, and pressed at 10 MPa for 5 min. The impedances were measured with a frequency response analyzer/potentiostat (PARSTAT 4000, Ametek, USA) over a frequency range from 0.1 Hz to 10 MHz, with a quasi-four probe electrochemical cell and an applied ac voltage of 500 mV. Measurements were taken in the temperature range of 30-90% RH with 90 °C and 30-90 °C with 90% RH (controlled by using an HDHWHS-50 incubator). Zview software was used to extrapolate impedance data results by means of an equivalent circuit simulation to complete the Nyquist plots and obtain the resistance values. Conductivity was calculated using the following equation: σ = L/(RS), where σ is the conductivity (S cm-1), L is the measured sample thickness (cm), S is the electrode area (cm2), and R is the impedance (Ω).

elements.content: Data collections were performed on a Bruker D8-Venture diffractometer with a Turbo X-ray Source (Mo–Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) adopting the direct drive rotating anode technique and a CMOS detector at room temperature. The data frames were collected using the program APEX2 and processed using the program SAINT routine in APEX2. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-2014 program. For both compounds, the solvent molecules in the structure were highly disordered and impossible to refine using the conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve this issue, the contribution of solvent-electron density was removed using the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, thereby producing a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formulas were calculated from the SQUEEZE results in combination with TGA measurement. Crystallographic and refinement details of compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Analysis

Data collections were performed on a Bruker D8-Venture diffractometer with a Turbo X-ray Source (Mo-Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) adopting the direct drive rotating anode technique and a CMOS detector at room temperature. The data frames were collected using the program APEX2 and processed using the program SAINT routine in APEX2. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-2014 program. For both compounds, the solvent molecules in the structure were highly disordered and impossible to refine using the conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve this issue, the contribution of solvent-electron density was removed using the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON, thereby producing a set of solvent-free diffraction intensities. The final formulas were calculated from the SQUEEZE results in combination with TGA measurement. Crystallographic and refinement details of compounds 1 and 2 are summarized in .

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for Compounds <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> sample compound 1 compound 2 formula C28H20CeN2O8 C30H29N3O10Ce mass 652.58 784.36 crystal system monoclinic hexagonal space group C2/c P63 a (Å) 20.0073(10) 15.9104(14) b (Å) 20.9035(10) 15.9104(14) c (Å) 8.9515(4) 14.7913(12) α (deg) 90 90 β (deg) 113.186(3) 90 γ (deg) 90 120 V (A3) 3441.3(3) 3242.6(6) Z 4 2 ρ (g cm–3) 1.260 1.104 μ (mm–1) 1.364 0.764 F (000) 1464 1080 T (K) 293(2) 293(2) GOF on F 2 1.000 1.086 R1, ωR2 (I > 2σ(I)) , 0.0227, 0.0639 0.0644, 0.1719 R1, ωR2 (all data) , 0.0273, 0.0656 0.1037, 0.1926

R1 = ∑||F c| – |F c|/∑|F o|.

ωR2 = [∑{ω­(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑ω­(F o 2)2}1/2.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group of C2/c and features a 3D framework composed of the metal chains of the cerium–carboxylate subunit. As shown in a, the asymmetric unit of compound 1 consists of half of a cerium­(III) ion and one ligand (Ccbp–). Each cerium­(III) cation is eight-coordinate, displaying a dodecahedron geometry with eight oxygens from eight different carboxylate groups of ligands. The overall coordination geometry of Ce­(III) ion may be described as a standard D 4d square antiprism. Each carboxylate group from the Ccbp– ligand bridges two Ce­(III) centers, and every two Ce­(III) are coordinated to four ligands, generating a metal–carboxylate chain (b). Every two adjacent Ce­(III) centers in the chains are bridged by four different carboxylate groups. Quadridentate ligand Ccbp– binds to four Ce­(III) centers, and each Ccbp– is connected to two metal chains, affording a 3D framework (d). The Ce–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.4649(54)–2.5359(57) Å in compound 1, which are comparable to the corresponding bond lengths of reported Ce­(III) complexes. c shows that the N–C–C torsion angles of the Ccbp are 109.780, 108.974, 106.249, and 102.766°, respectively, deviating significantly from the standard C–C–C bond angle of 109°. This initially suggests the decent chance of phase transition given the intrinsic instability origin of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group of C2/c and features a 3D framework composed of the metal chains of the cerium-carboxylate subunit. As shown in a, the asymmetric unit of compound 1 consists of half of a cerium(III) ion and one ligand (Ccbp-). Each cerium(III) cation is eight-coordinate, displaying a dodecahedron geometry with eight oxygens from eight different carboxylate groups of ligands. The overall coordination geometry of Ce(III) ion may be described as a standard D 4d  square antiprism. Each carboxylate group from the Ccbp- ligand bridges two Ce(III) centers, and every two Ce(III) are coordinated to four ligands, generating a metal-carboxylate chain (b). Every two adjacent Ce(III) centers in the chains are bridged by four different carboxylate groups. Quadridentate ligand Ccbp- binds to four Ce(III) centers, and each Ccbp- is connected to two metal chains, affording a 3D framework (d). The Ce-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.4649(54)-2.5359(57) Å in compound 1, which are comparable to the corresponding bond lengths of reported Ce(III) complexes. c shows that the N-C-C torsion angles of the Ccbp are 109.780, 108.974, 106.249, and 102.766°, respectively, deviating significantly from the standard C-C-C bond angle of 109°. This initially suggests the decent chance of phase transition given the intrinsic instability origin of the framework.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric unit of compound 1. (b) Metal–carboxylate chain in compound 1. (c) Torsion angle of the Ccbp ligand. (d) Three-dimensional framework structure of compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The asymmetric unit of compound 1. (b) Metal-carboxylate chain in compound 1. (c) Torsion angle of the Ccbp ligand. (d) Three-dimensional framework structure of compound 1.

elements.content: In the self-assemble process, the formal charge of the ligand would be changed associated with the deprotonation and coordination. When the ligand is deprotonated, its valence is −1. Since there is no other anionic ligand such as oxide/​hydroxide observed in the framework, compound 1 is clearly a cationic framework. The charge-balancing Br– is unable to identify in the electron density map, indicating that Br– is highly disordered in the voids, suggesting its anion-exchange potential at the first place. The charge-balancing bromide anion can be further probed by the EDX measurement (Figure S5). An anion-exchange experiment was, therefore, conducted in DMF to initially evaluate its removal capacity for the highly toxic anion CrO4 2–. The result shows that compound 1 can remove 50% CrO4 2– from DMF solution (Figure S3), which was further confirmed by the EDX analysis (Figure S5). This again verified the cationic nature of compound 1. Combining the powder X-ray diffraction data, these studies reveal that not only anion-exchange occurs but also the structure remains intact throughout the exchange.
elements.clean_text: In the self-assemble process, the formal charge of the ligand would be changed associated with the deprotonation and coordination. When the ligand is deprotonated, its valence is -1. Since there is no other anionic ligand such as oxide/hydroxide observed in the framework, compound 1 is clearly a cationic framework. The charge-balancing Br- is unable to identify in the electron density map, indicating that Br- is highly disordered in the voids, suggesting its anion-exchange potential at the first place. The charge-balancing bromide anion can be further probed by the EDX measurement (Figure S5). An anion-exchange experiment was, therefore, conducted in DMF to initially evaluate its removal capacity for the highly toxic anion CrO4 2-. The result shows that compound 1 can remove 50% CrO4 2- from DMF solution (Figure S3), which was further confirmed by the EDX analysis (Figure S5). This again verified the cationic nature of compound 1. Combining the powder X-ray diffraction data, these studies reveal that not only anion-exchange occurs but also the structure remains intact throughout the exchange.

elements.content: Many proton-conducting MOFs reported were filled with proton carriers such as water in confined void spaces and are often operated at room temperature and under high-humidity conditions. Given that there are abundant free water molecules in voids of compound 1, proton-conducting measurement was initially conducted from 30% RH to 90% RH at 90 °C. Interestingly, at 30% RH, compound 1 does not exhibit proton-conducting behavior. When the humidity is increased to 40% RH, a proton conductivity of 3.10 × 10–7 S cm–1 was observed, while it further increases sharply by at least 6 times to 1.92 × 10–6 S cm–1 at 50% RH (). Afterward, as shown in a, with the increasing of the humidity, the proton conductivity is proportional to water content with no drastic change. Such a sharp humidity-dependent feature of the proton-conducting behavior at the beginning suggests the occurrence of water-induced phase transition under the relatively low humidity. Kitagawa and his co-workers reported a water adsorption/desorption processes leading to phase transition from a 2-D to a 1-D channel hydrogen-bonding network, leading to a sharp rise of conductivity from 10–12 to 10–2 S cm–1 above 95% RH. To verify the hypothesis of phase transition, powder X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out for the sample after proton-conducting measurement. Inspiringly, a new substance clearly different from compound 1 was discovered as shown in .
elements.clean_text: Many proton-conducting MOFs reported were filled with proton carriers such as water in confined void spaces and are often operated at room temperature and under high-humidity conditions. Given that there are abundant free water molecules in voids of compound 1, proton-conducting measurement was initially conducted from 30% RH to 90% RH at 90 °C. Interestingly, at 30% RH, compound 1 does not exhibit proton-conducting behavior. When the humidity is increased to 40% RH, a proton conductivity of 3.10 × 10-7 S cm-1 was observed, while it further increases sharply by at least 6 times to 1.92 × 10-6 S cm-1 at 50% RH (). Afterward, as shown in a, with the increasing of the humidity, the proton conductivity is proportional to water content with no drastic change. Such a sharp humidity-dependent feature of the proton-conducting behavior at the beginning suggests the occurrence of water-induced phase transition under the relatively low humidity. Kitagawa and his co-workers reported a water adsorption/desorption processes leading to phase transition from a 2-D to a 1-D channel hydrogen-bonding network, leading to a sharp rise of conductivity from 10-12 to 10-2 S cm-1 above 95% RH. To verify the hypothesis of phase transition, powder X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out for the sample after proton-conducting measurement. Inspiringly, a new substance clearly different from compound 1 was discovered as shown in .

elements.content: We also investigated the water vapor adsorption and desorption isotherm of compound 1 (Figure S7). These two curves are not overlapped with each other (i.e., a hysteresis loop is present), which also hints for the occurrence of phase transformation after contacting with water.
elements.clean_text: We also investigated the water vapor adsorption and desorption isotherm of compound 1 (Figure S7). These two curves are not overlapped with each other (i.e., a hysteresis loop is present), which also hints for the occurrence of phase transformation after contacting with water.

elements.content: To complete the transformation from compound 1 to compound 2, a dry sample of compound 1 was soaked into water. Interestingly, the color of the sample instantly changed from dark yellow to light yellow with the contact of water (). In addition to the color mutation, this transformation can be also probed by the discrepant absorption spectra of the solids of two compounds. As shown in , the UV–vis absorption spectra of the compound 1, compound 2, and ligand all display intense absorption bands in the high-energy region (λ < 300 nm) associated with the π → π* transition of the ligand, while compounds 1 and 2 exhibit low energy bands in the range of 300–500 nm, which may be assigned as the charge transfer between the Ce3+ and Ccbp ligand. The characteristic peak intensity reduction corresponds to the color change from compound 1 to compound 2.
elements.clean_text: To complete the transformation from compound 1 to compound 2, a dry sample of compound 1 was soaked into water. Interestingly, the color of the sample instantly changed from dark yellow to light yellow with the contact of water (). In addition to the color mutation, this transformation can be also probed by the discrepant absorption spectra of the solids of two compounds. As shown in , the UV-vis absorption spectra of the compound 1, compound 2, and ligand all display intense absorption bands in the high-energy region (λ < 300 nm) associated with the π → π* transition of the ligand, while compounds 1 and 2 exhibit low energy bands in the range of 300-500 nm, which may be assigned as the charge transfer between the Ce3+ and Ccbp ligand. The characteristic peak intensity reduction corresponds to the color change from compound 1 to compound 2.

elements.content: The color change of compounds 1 and 2 and the corresponding absorption spectra.
elements.clean_text: 4  The color change of compounds 1 and 2 and the corresponding absorption spectra.

elements.content: We further performed single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis on compound 2 to further understand the transformation mechanism. The result reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P63 and contains a series of 1D neutral chains. The triple-stranded chains consist of a central Ce­(III) center coordinated by nine oxygen atoms from six Ccbp ligands and three water molecules. The Ce center sits on the 3-fold axis (a), and its overall local coordination geometry can be best described as a 9-coordinate monocapped square antiprism. Every two adjacent Ce­(III) ions are bridged by three Ccbp ligands through six terminal carboxylate groups in a monodentate coordination mode (a). Conformational versatility is a common phenomenon for flexible ligands. b shows that the N–C–C torsion angles of the Ccbp are 107.998° (nearly close to 109°) which contrast sharply with those of compound 1, suggesting the stability of compound 2 would be elevated. This is confirmed by the fact that the structure of compound 2 remains intact in water.
elements.clean_text: We further performed single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis on compound 2 to further understand the transformation mechanism. The result reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P63 and contains a series of 1D neutral chains. The triple-stranded chains consist of a central Ce(III) center coordinated by nine oxygen atoms from six Ccbp ligands and three water molecules. The Ce center sits on the 3-fold axis (a), and its overall local coordination geometry can be best described as a 9-coordinate monocapped square antiprism. Every two adjacent Ce(III) ions are bridged by three Ccbp ligands through six terminal carboxylate groups in a monodentate coordination mode (a). Conformational versatility is a common phenomenon for flexible ligands. b shows that the N-C-C torsion angles of the Ccbp are 107.998° (nearly close to 109°) which contrast sharply with those of compound 1, suggesting the stability of compound 2 would be elevated. This is confirmed by the fact that the structure of compound 2 remains intact in water.

elements.content: (a) The asymmetric unit of compound 2. (b) Torsion angle of the Ccbp of compound 2. (c) One-dimensional structure of compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) The asymmetric unit of compound 2. (b) Torsion angle of the Ccbp of compound 2. (c) One-dimensional structure of compound 2.

elements.content: The possible process of phase transition is depicted in . We propose that water molecules can move rapidly into the channels of compound 1, attacking the Ce­(III) sites of high hydrophilicity, forming Ce–Ow bonds. The framework structure soon rearranges drove by intrinsic instability origin that the torsion angles of the Ccbp significantly deviate from the standard value. The unbound halide anions are further substituted by the bridging Ccbp– ligand, leading to a transformation of a cationic 3D framework into a neutral chain with a noticeably increased amount of both coordinated and lattice water molecules. This process would involve partial releasing of Ce­(III) halide salts back into the aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: The possible process of phase transition is depicted in . We propose that water molecules can move rapidly into the channels of compound 1, attacking the Ce(III) sites of high hydrophilicity, forming Ce-Ow bonds. The framework structure soon rearranges drove by intrinsic instability origin that the torsion angles of the Ccbp significantly deviate from the standard value. The unbound halide anions are further substituted by the bridging Ccbp- ligand, leading to a transformation of a cationic 3D framework into a neutral chain with a noticeably increased amount of both coordinated and lattice water molecules. This process would involve partial releasing of Ce(III) halide salts back into the aqueous solution.

elements.content: Diagram showing the possible process of phase transition from compound 1 to compound 2.
elements.clean_text: 6  Diagram showing the possible process of phase transition from compound 1 to compound 2.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric measurements were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As illustrated in the , compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. For compound 1, the first weight loss of 4.6% in the range of 30–120 °C was assigned to the removal of guest molecules DMF and water, followed by the framework decomposition. Weight losses of compound 2 can be divided into three distinct stages. The first stage from 30 to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of volatilization of physically adsorbed water and residual solvent in the void space. In the second stage (100–260 °C), the weight loss is clearly an elevation compared to that of compound 1 owing to the existence of coordinated water molecules. The third stage (>260 °C) suggests the destruction of the basic skeleton of compound 2.
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric measurements were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. As illustrated in the , compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. For compound 1, the first weight loss of 4.6% in the range of 30-120 °C was assigned to the removal of guest molecules DMF and water, followed by the framework decomposition. Weight losses of compound 2 can be divided into three distinct stages. The first stage from 30 to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of volatilization of physically adsorbed water and residual solvent in the void space. In the second stage (100-260 °C), the weight loss is clearly an elevation compared to that of compound 1 owing to the existence of coordinated water molecules. The third stage (>260 °C) suggests the destruction of the basic skeleton of compound 2.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of compounds 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 7  Thermogravimetric analysis of compounds 1 and 2.

elements.content: FT-IR analysis was further carried out to verify the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. Figure S2 illustrates that two compounds contain almost identical broad features in the range from 500 to 2500 cm–1. The broad peak located at 3390–3450 cm–1, attributed to the vibrations of the water molecules, indicates the presence of lattice and coordinated water molecules. This feature in compound 2 is stronger than that in compound 1, consistent with fact of water anticipation during the phase transition.
elements.clean_text: FT-IR analysis was further carried out to verify the single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. Figure S2 illustrates that two compounds contain almost identical broad features in the range from 500 to 2500 cm-1. The broad peak located at 3390-3450 cm-1, attributed to the vibrations of the water molecules, indicates the presence of lattice and coordinated water molecules. This feature in compound 2 is stronger than that in compound 1, consistent with fact of water anticipation during the phase transition.

elements.content: Finally, to assess the proton conductivity after complete phase transition, ac impedance analysis was carried out directly on compound 2 at 90 °C and 30%–90% RH. The results show that proton conductivity is almost directly proportional to the water content with no sudden change (shown in b). The proton conductivities of compound 2 at low humidity 30% RH and 40% RH are both higher than those of compound 1, at 1.736 × 10–5 and 2.514× 10–5 S cm–1, respectively. In addition, there is no obvious difference for the proton-conducting behavior at a humidity higher than 50% RH with that of compound 2 (Figure S6). These observations further affirmed the process of phase transition. Furthermore, an increase in conductivity with increasing temperature was observed at 90% RH, as shown in the . The highest conductivity was 1.104 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 90 °C and 90% RH. As shown in d, the conductivity of compound 2 was found to follow the linear relationship with temperature in the Arrhenius plot. The activation energy (E a) of this conductivity was calculated to be 0.6 eV (>0.4 eV), which indicates the vehicular mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Finally, to assess the proton conductivity after complete phase transition, ac impedance analysis was carried out directly on compound 2 at 90 °C and 30%-90% RH. The results show that proton conductivity is almost directly proportional to the water content with no sudden change (shown in  b). The proton conductivities of compound 2 at low humidity 30% RH and 40% RH are both higher than those of compound 1, at 1.736 × 10-5 and 2.514× 10-5 S cm-1, respectively. In addition, there is no obvious difference for the proton-conducting behavior at a humidity higher than 50% RH with that of compound 2 (Figure S6). These observations further affirmed the process of phase transition. Furthermore, an increase in conductivity with increasing temperature was observed at 90% RH, as shown in the . The highest conductivity was 1.104 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 90 °C and 90% RH. As shown in d, the conductivity of compound 2 was found to follow the linear relationship with temperature in the Arrhenius plot. The activation energy (E a) of this conductivity was calculated to be 0.6 eV (>0.4 eV), which indicates the vehicular mechanism.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have demonstrated an unusual case of water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transformation from a 3D porous cationic MOF compound 1 to a 1D neutral chain structure compound 2. This process was originally probed by the humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements and further confirmed by combined color change, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR and UV–vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis. This type of phase transition is not typical for a lanthanide-based MOF system given that most of the lanthanide-based MOFs are hydrolytically stable. It allows for introducing large amounts of water content into the structure, providing a new method to enhance the proton conductivity in flexible MOFs materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have demonstrated an unusual case of water-induced single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transformation from a 3D porous cationic MOF compound 1 to a 1D neutral chain structure compound 2. This process was originally probed by the humidity-dependent proton-conducting measurements and further confirmed by combined color change, powder X-ray diffraction, single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR and UV-vis spectroscopies, and thermogravimetric analysis. This type of phase transition is not typical for a lanthanide-based MOF system given that most of the lanthanide-based MOFs are hydrolytically stable. It allows for introducing large amounts of water content into the structure, providing a new method to enhance the proton conductivity in flexible MOFs materials.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of 4-(bromo­methyl)­benzoic acid (3.5 g, 15 mmol) and ethyl isonicotinate (2.3 g, 15 mmol) in 50 mL of CH3CN was refluxed for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled down to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried at 50 °C to give the ester of H2Ccbp­Br. The resultant was dissolved in 15% HCl (w/w; 60 mL) and was subsequently refluxed for 6 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white power, which was recrystallized in H2O to afford colorless crystals.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>1</bold>

Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction. A reactant mixture of H2Ccbp­Br (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), Ce­(NH4)2­(NO3)6 (54.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (1 mL) was loaded into a 20 mL glass vial and heated at 100 °C for 5 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The product was obtained as dark yellow block-shaped crystals (yield: 67% based on cerium), recovered by filtration, and subsequently washed with DMF and ethanol. Yield: ca. 55.3% (based on Ce­(NH4)2­(NO3)6). Anal. Calcd for C34H56­O16N4­Cl0.75Br0.25­Ce: C, 45.02%; H, 4.634%; N, 6.17%; Found: C, 44.15%; H, 4.208%; N, 5.947%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was conducted to verify the purity of compound 1 (Figure S1).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ligand H2CcbpBr

A mixture of 4-(bromomethyl)benzoic acid (3.5 g, 15 mmol) and ethyl isonicotinate (2.3 g, 15 mmol) in 50 mL of CH3CN was refluxed for 3 days. After the mixture was cooled down to room temperature, the resulting precipitate was filtered, washed with CH3CN, and dried at 50 °C to give the ester of H2CcbpBr. The resultant was dissolved in 15% HCl (w/w; 60 mL) and was subsequently refluxed for 6 h. The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white power, which was recrystallized in H2O to afford colorless crystals.

Synthesis of Compound 1 

Compound 1 was synthesized by solvothermal reaction. A reactant mixture of H2CcbpBr (25.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6 (54.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (4 mL), and H2O (1 mL) was loaded into a 20 mL glass vial and heated at 100 °C for 5 h, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The product was obtained as dark yellow block-shaped crystals (yield: 67% based on cerium), recovered by filtration, and subsequently washed with DMF and ethanol. Yield: ca. 55.3% (based on Ce(NH4)2(NO3)6). Anal. Calcd for C34H56O16N4Cl0.75Br0.25Ce: C, 45.02%; H, 4.634%; N, 6.17%; Found: C, 44.15%; H, 4.208%; N, 5.947%. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was conducted to verify the purity of compound 1 (Figure S1).

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric measurements were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As illustrated in the , compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. For compound 1, the first weight loss of 4.6% in the range of 30–120 °C was assigned to the removal of guest molecules DMF and water, followed by the framework decomposition. Weight losses of compound 2 can be divided into three distinct stages. The first stage from 30 to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of volatilization of physically adsorbed water and residual solvent in the void space. In the second stage (100–260 °C), the weight loss is clearly an elevation compared to that of compound 1 owing to the existence of coordinated water molecules. The third stage (>260 °C) suggests the destruction of the basic skeleton of compound 2.

Finally, to assess the proton conductivity after complete phase transition, ac impedance analysis was carried out directly on compound 2 at 90 °C and 30%–90% RH. The results show that proton conductivity is almost directly proportional to the water content with no sudden change (shown in b). The proton conductivities of compound 2 at low humidity 30% RH and 40% RH are both higher than those of compound 1, at 1.736 × 10–5 and 2.514× 10–5 S cm–1, respectively. In addition, there is no obvious difference for the proton-conducting behavior at a humidity higher than 50% RH with that of compound 2 (Figure S6). These observations further affirmed the process of phase transition. Furthermore, an increase in conductivity with increasing temperature was observed at 90% RH, as shown in the . The highest conductivity was 1.104 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 90 °C and 90% RH. As shown in d, the conductivity of compound 2 was found to follow the linear relationship with temperature in the Arrhenius plot. The activation energy (E a) of this conductivity was calculated to be 0.6 eV (>0.4 eV), which indicates the vehicular mechanism.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric measurements were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. As illustrated in the , compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to ca. 260 °C. For compound 1, the first weight loss of 4.6% in the range of 30-120 °C was assigned to the removal of guest molecules DMF and water, followed by the framework decomposition. Weight losses of compound 2 can be divided into three distinct stages. The first stage from 30 to 100 °C corresponds to the loss of volatilization of physically adsorbed water and residual solvent in the void space. In the second stage (100-260 °C), the weight loss is clearly an elevation compared to that of compound 1 owing to the existence of coordinated water molecules. The third stage (>260 °C) suggests the destruction of the basic skeleton of compound 2.

Finally, to assess the proton conductivity after complete phase transition, ac impedance analysis was carried out directly on compound 2 at 90 °C and 30%-90% RH. The results show that proton conductivity is almost directly proportional to the water content with no sudden change (shown in  b). The proton conductivities of compound 2 at low humidity 30% RH and 40% RH are both higher than those of compound 1, at 1.736 × 10-5 and 2.514× 10-5 S cm-1, respectively. In addition, there is no obvious difference for the proton-conducting behavior at a humidity higher than 50% RH with that of compound 2 (Figure S6). These observations further affirmed the process of phase transition. Furthermore, an increase in conductivity with increasing temperature was observed at 90% RH, as shown in the . The highest conductivity was 1.104 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 90 °C and 90% RH. As shown in d, the conductivity of compound 2 was found to follow the linear relationship with temperature in the Arrhenius plot. The activation energy (E a) of this conductivity was calculated to be 0.6 eV (>0.4 eV), which indicates the vehicular mechanism.

metadata.title:
Significant Proton Conductivity Enhancement through
Rapid Water-Induced Structural Transformation from a Cationic Framework
to a Water-Rich Neutral Chain
